Home

I am a NASA Einstein postdoctoral fellow in astrophysics working at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and the California Institute of Technology as part of the TAPIR group. I am interested in several topics in pulsar timing such as gravitational wave detection, noise modeling, dispersion measure variations, testing general relativity and alternative theories of gravity, and the appication of Bayesian data analysis tecnhiques to all areas of pulsar timing and beyond. I am a member of the North American Nanohertz Observatory for Gravitational Waves (NANOGrav) and the International Pulsar Timing Array (IPTA). Currently I am the Chair of the Gravitational Wave Detection group in NANOGrav and am active in both the timing and interstellar medium mitigation (IMM) working groups. Check out my Research page for more information about my work.

Before becoming an Einstein fellow, I completed my Bachelors degree in physics at West Virginia University and then obtained my Ph.D from the University of Wisconsin Milwaukee under the supervision of Xavier Siemens.

Check out my Blog for some good old fashioned rants, research news and updates, movie and TV reviews, and the occasional ethical dilemma.
